qas.question: What happens when an anesthetic injection is directed into the nerves a limb stump?
How long can an anesthetic, at max, relieve pain for, despite wearing off in only hours?
What is injected in small amounts into the soft tissue between vertebrae to produce local pain?
Vibrating the stump of an amputee's limb can produce what in some patients?

plausible_answers.text: relieve pain for days, weeks, or sometimes permanently

qas.question: What happens when an injection is placed into nerves?

plausible_answers.text: the nerves or sensitive areas of the stump

context: Local anesthetic injections into <b5_0>the nerves or sensitive areas of the stump<b5_0/> <a0_0>may <b4_0>relieve pain<a0_0/> for days, weeks, or sometimes <a1_0>permanently<b4_0/><a1_0/>, despite the drug wearing off in a matter of hours; and small injections of <a2_0>hypertonic saline<a2_0/> into the soft tissue between vertebrae produces local pain that radiates into the phantom limb for ten minutes or so and may be followed by hours, weeks or even longer of partial or total relief from phantom pain. Vigorous vibration or electrical stimulation of the stump, or current from electrodes surgically implanted onto the spinal cord, all produce <a3_0><b6_0><b7_0>relief<a3_0/> in some patients<b7_0/><b6_0/>.
